bboxes.raw_text:
TRIBUNE PUBLISHER
TO ATTEND NNPA MID
WINTER MEET

WASHINGTON Four Negro
leaders talked for more than
an hour with President Johnson
about civil rights and his cam
paign against poverty.


The Negro leaders said John
son shares their hope the civil
rights bill will reach the House
floor by the end of January.


DR.. Martin Luther King. Jr.,
head of the Southern Christian
Leadership conference. said the
meeting delt mainly with John
sons forthcoming message to
Congress on antipoverty legis-
lation.


Roy wilkins, executive secre-
tary of the National Association
for the Advancement of Colored

CLEVELAND = Fora Foley of
Chandler, sixth ranked heavy
weight fighter, won unanimous
decision in a 10 round nationally
teleMsed bout last Friday.


Foley looked sharp and moved
around quickly. using his left jab
effectively.


Neither fighter received any
damaging punches. There were
no knockdowns.


Foley. the father Of seven
lasted three rounds with Sonny
Liston. the heavyweight cham
pion, in 1860. He would like
a match with him again.

FOLEY WINS
OHIO MATCH

Edward Banks, publisher-edi-
tor of the Arizona Tribune, will
attend the annual midwtnter
workshop of the National News
paper Publishers Assn. in Wash
ington Jan. 2o-Feb. l..


Workshop headquarters will be
at the International Inn.


NNPA President E. Washington
Rhodes, publisher of the Phila-
delphia Tribune. said the theme
will be conferred on the role Of
newspapers. in the civil rights
program.


Members of the NlNPA will
confer with President Lyndon B.
Johnson at the White House on
Jan. 30th.

People, said Johnson agreed with
them that the civil rights bill
should be passed as soon as pos
sible. The goal is to have 1t on
the House floor before the end of
the month.


Whitney Young, executive di-
rector of the Urban League, said
he told Johnson that one out of
every four Negroes is without a
job and that 500. 900 Negroes be-
tween the ages of 10 and 81 are
out of school and out of work.
James Farmer, national direc-
tor of the Congress of Racial
Equality. said he urged a rene
dial education program on a mas
sive scale, including job refrain
ing.

d NEGRO LEADERS
MEET WITHLBJ

Carl Rowan, ambassador to
Finland, was named to replace
Edward R. Murrow as director Of
the u. S. Information Agency.
President Johnson announced Ro-
vans appointment early this
week.


Rowan, 38. a Negro. is for
mer newspaperman and author.
becomes the highest ranking Ne
gro in the federal government and
becomes the first Negro to at
tend National Security Council
meetings.


The new USIA director is ma
tive of Ravenscroft, Tenn. he
spent his early years in McMinn-
Vile, Tenn, and attended Ten
fiessee State University at Nash
Vile. At lo he was one OF the
first Is Negroes commissioned
in the Navy.


Following World War Two he
received a bachelors degree In
mathematics from Oberlin Col
lege. Oberlin Ohio. and a mas
ter's degree in journalism at
the University Of Minnesota In
1913.


AS a writer on the Minneapolis
Tribune, Rowan won many ma
tional awards.


In February 1861, he was
named an assistant secretary OF
state, later he became the ambas-
sador to Finland.


His appointment must be con-
firmed by the Senate.

ROWAN NAMED
USA HEAD TO
SUCCEED MURROW

BIRMINGHAM. Ala An all
white jury convicted a white boy,
16, of second-degree manslaugh-
ter in the Staying of Negro
youth Sept. is. during the after
math of a church bombing.


Larry Joe Sims was sentenced
to seven months in the county
jail. The l2-man jury deliberated
four hours.


Sims, an Eagle Scout, had
been charged with first-degree
murder In the Staying of Virgil
Ware, Is, Negro.


The shooting occurred several
hours after the 10th Street Bap-
fist Church was bombed. Four
Negro girls died in the blast.
JURY CONVICTS BOY

James Montgomery was found
guilty Monday of involuntary
manslaughter in connection with
the Sept. II rifle Staying Of his
common-law wife, Georgia
Davis, 19.


Sentencing was set for 1880
pm. Jan. u by Judge William
A. Holohan.


Prosecutor Richard Brennan
maintained Montgomery. 49, of
PAPA E. Pueblo shot the Davis
woman in the head twice when
she threatened to leave him and
go to California. Montgomery
unsuccessfully attempted to
commit suicide after the Staying
by shooting himself in the chest.


Defense attorney Walter Kess-
Ter contended that the shooting
was accidental. Montgomery tes-
titled to that effect himself dur
ing the three-day trial.

MONTGOMERY
FOUND GUILTY

NEW YORK A car was stolen
every 90 seconds in the United
States last year.


The National Automobile Theft
Bureau said the thefts, up lis
per cent over 1862, totaled
100000 cars, worth 1915 mil
lion. Auto theft is the nation S
costliest crime involving pro-
perty it said.
STOLEN CARS

The Committee ON Public Institutions has
sponsored House Bill 81 which would create
q state Human Re l0tiOmS Commits SiOn For
several years The Arizona Tribune has 0d-
U0cated the establishment Of such a body. A
statewide human re l0tiOuS COMM SsiOn has
bYoUed effe ctiUe IN nearly half Of the states
in the nation.


The proposed commits sion Mould be COM
posed Of persons appointed by the governor
with senate consent. Members Mould serve
without pay for tive year terms.


The commits sion could SeTUe as central
sounding board for grievances which occur
in the state. 1t could effectively study, and
PROPOSE remedies for minority group prob
lens.


Presently there is no agency IN the state
which has the accurate reports of minority
GROUP problems other than the state en-
bloymgent service.


The three Negro Legislators should COM
bime efforts and support passage Of House
Bill 81. A state Human Re lati0nS Commits
sion is needed.
Human Relations Commission

Burglars took an estimated
$4o5 and a television set from
a Phoenix home, police reported.


Joseph Jofar, 49,, of 1917 S.
Sixth Ave., said he found the
money and television set missing
when he returned home from
work.

BURGLARS ROB
PHOENIX MAN

WASHINGTON Howard Uni
versity announced a program to
prepare Negroes, Puerto Ricans
and Americans of Mexican de-
scent for careers in the foreign
service.
MINORITY GROUPS SOUGHT FOR FOREIGN SER.

The project slated to begin in
June will be administered by
Howard in cooperation with agen-
cies of the federal government.
